title: Meghan Markle will meet young leaders fighting for gender equality
text:
The Duchess of Sussex attends the opening ceremony of the One Young World Summit at the Royal Albert Hall in London on Tuesday

The Duchess of Sussex will join young leaders from around the world for a roundtable discussion on gender equality at Windsor Castle tomorrow.

Meghan will meet young people leading projects and ventures backing inclusion in countries including South Africa, Nigeria, Iraq, Malawi and Bangladesh.

Buckingham Palace said Prince Harry's wife would attend the event which has been planned with One Young World and the Queen's Commonwealth Trust.

A royal spokesman said this afternoon: 'The discussion will cover how these young leaders are driving meaningful change for empowering women.

'They will share achievements and best practices that have helped empower communities to overcome complex challenges and significant obstacles.'

Meanwhile, Buckingham Palace also announced that Harry will attend the launch of Team UK for the Invictus Games The Hague 2020 next Tuesday.

Meghan's discussion will be led by QCT chief executive Nicola Brentnall with moderation from OYW counsellors Rosanna Burgos and Mark Tewksbury.

The QCT, which Meghan serves as vice-president, aims to champion, connect and fund young leaders from the 53 countries in the Commonwealth.

The roundtable will come three days after Meghan attended the official opening of the OYW summit at London's Royal Albert Hall on Tuesday night.

Cheers from the audience greeted Meghan on Tuesday as she was welcomed on to the stage as 'a global champion for the rights of women and girls, activist and philanthropist'

Cheers from the audience greeted her as she was welcomed on to the stage as 'a global champion for the rights of women and girls, activist and philanthropist'.

The summit is billed as a global forum for young leaders, bringing together 2,000 people from over 190 countries around the world pushing for social impact.

Her appearance at the ceremony was her first amid the debate over the Duke and Duchess's state of mind after an interview with ITV shown on Sunday.

Since then it has also emerged that the Duchess will appear in an archive photograph on the cover of Tatler for the magazine's 310th anniversary issue.

The Duke and Duchess of Sussex are pictured in South Africa on October 2 during their tour

The Duchess will appear on the cover of Tatler for the magazine's 310th anniversary issue

It debates 'The Meghan issue', with the cover headline asking 'Does she conquer or divide?' and writers such as Lionel Shriver and Lynn Barber 'taking sides'.

Harry will attend Team UK launch for Invictus Games next Tuesday Buckingham Palace also announced that the Duke of Sussex will attend the launch of Team UK for the Invictus Games The Hague 2020 next week. Harry is to join the 65-strong squad of wounded, injured and sick service personnel on Tuesday, October 29 as they come together for the first time at the Honourable Artillery Company in London. The duke, patron of the Invictus Games Foundation, will meet the competitors and pose for the first official team photo.

Yesterday, a source close to Harry and Meghan said they have 'single-handedly modernised the monarchy' – but courtiers are stoking up 'hysteria' against them.

In astonishing claims, the adviser accused the courtiers of being 'afraid of and inexperienced at how to best help harness and deploy the value' of the Sussexes.

As the fallout over the interview continued, the source even suggested that palace insiders were hell-bent on stoking up 'anti-Prince Harry and Meghan hysteria'.

Sources close to the couple are unapologetic about the furore caused by their documentary with ITV journalist Tom Bradby, Harry & Meghan: An African Journey.

An aide said they thought it was 'sympathetic and balanced', and showed 'some of the real behind the scenes pressures' of a royal tour and their lives.
description: Meghan will be at Windsor Castle tomorrow to meet young people leading projects and ventures backing inclusion in countries including South Africa, Nigeria, Iraq, Malawi and Bangladesh.
